abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of the project is rated
            satisfactory. Despite the lack of counterpart funding, which
            was persistent during implementation, and a poor progress in
            the decentralization process, the Micro-projects Unit (MPU)
            managed implementation satisfactorily. The extent to which
            poor communities can effectively operate was successfully
            demonstrated, reconfirming the benefits of stakeholder
            participation and capacity building at local levels. Lessons
            are addressed specifically for social funds development,
            showing the need for these funds to build institutional
            linkages, ensuring coherence and sustainability,
            particularly at local and community levels, safeguarding
            local characteristics. Social funds should operate within
            unified policies and procedures, in comparison with
            financing agencies, where discrepancies may well hinder an
            efficient implementation, as well as operational
            development. In addition, technical support during
            supervision increases project success, thus quality of
            infrastructure should be closely monitored. Increasing
            community ownership and commitment may, to some extent be a
            viable solution for the sustainability of those social funds
            affected by recurrent costs. Finally, MPU was responsive to
            recommendations due to its learning flexibility, thus
            adapting to the improvement and success of the project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will fund community
            initiatives to help mitigate the negative effects on the
            poor from the economic crisis.  It will support the
            rehabilitation and improvement of existing infrastructure
            and service delivery through the Microprojects Unit in the
            Ministry of Finance.  The project will strengthen
            communities' ability to improve their situation through
            self-help. Further, the project will improve the information
            base and provide analyses to enhance the Government's
            planning and policy making in the social sectors.  It
            consists of the following three components: (a) community
            initiatives which will finance a series of small, simple and
            locally-generated sub-projects in health, nutrition,
            education and economic infrastructure; (b) institutional
            support for the Microprojects Unit; (c) analysis and
            monitoring which includes support for national statistical
            surveys, a beneficiary assessment, and a studies fund that
            will finance a series of studies related to poverty and adjustment.
